title: Teaching and Learning Mathematics in the Changing Curriculum
requirements: For students in MSc Mathematics Education and Master of Education Teach Key Sub Area (NETTI)
description: This course offers an introduction to the theoretical aspects of mathematics teaching and learning in face of the challenge from the ever-changing mathematics curriculum. It will provide an overview of both cognitive and socio-psychological issues involved in both the teaching and the learning of mathematics. Topics include the psychological models or theories in the teaching and learning of mathematics; research on the teaching and learning of number, algebra, geometry, and calculus; developmental, sociocultural, semiotic, and approaches to the study of concepts and conceptual development; digital technology in mathematics teaching and learning; discourse and the situated nature of cognition; mathematical problem solving and problem posing; research on mathematics-related affect.
outcome: 1. Develop an understanding of the theoretical aspects of mathematics teaching and learning in face of the challenge from the ever-changing mathematics curriculum. 2. Demonstrate knowledge of an overview of the central issues related to the nature of teaching and learning from historical and cultural perspectives in relation to the ever-changing curriculum. 3. Critically examine issues related to the changing mathematics curriculum with reference to latest trends in technological innovations and theoretical research development in mathematics education. 4. Become familiar with significant theoretical constructs and empirical findings with reference to the psychology of mathematical problem-solving and the nature of learning mathematics in the classroom. 5. Become familiar with current issues in attitude and belief in mathematics learning, intelligence and disability, learning styles, and affect.  (Individual course teachers may update the learning outcome as and whenever necessary.)
syllabus: 1. Historical and contemporary perspectives on knowledge, teaching, and learning  2. Contemporary theories in mathematics education  3. Selected theoretical constructs about teaching and learning mathematics  (For reference only, please refer to the course outline of respective teacher for details.)

title: Mathematics Curriculum and Assessment Under Educational Reform
requirements: For students in MSc Mathematics Education
description: This course aims at helping students develop an understanding of the impact of educational reform on mathematics education by an in-depth analysis of current issues pertaining to the mathematics curriculum and assessment. From the perspective of curriculum design, the local curricula in both primary and secondary schools are delineated. The changing goals of mathematics education are addressed with reference to the historical development. Worldwide trends in mathematics curriculum development are also reviewed. Mathematics achievement and the ever-changing development in the assessment of mathematics learning are discussed. Other relevant current issues in curriculum development and teacher professionalism may also be explored.
outcome: 1. develop an understanding of the impact of educational reform on mathematics education, by an in-depth analysis of current curriculum issues 2. develop an understanding of the general principles of curriculum design of the current Hong Kong primary and secondary curriculum 3. advance their awareness and understanding of the key external and internal forces shaping the historical development and the changing goals of mathematics education, 4. enhance their abilities to analyze, evaluate, and reflect on the worldwide trends in mathematics curriculum development, 5. increase their awareness of the ever-changing development in the assessment issues, both at local and global levels, and  6. strengthen their abilities to analyze, evaluate, and reflect on other current curriculum development issues.   (Individual course teachers may update the learning outcome as and whenever necessary.)
syllabus: 1. The goals of mathematics education  2. The evolution of the Hong Kong mathematics curricula 3. Mathematics curriculum development 4. Mathematics curriculum evaluation 5. Analysis of the current Hong Kong mathematics curriculum 6. Designing mathematics curricula for specific target groups 7. Focal points of the Hong Kong mathematics curriculum 8. Assessment issues in focus 9. Emergent issues in mathematics curriculum 10. Trends of the mathematics curricula worldwide  (For reference only, please refer to the course outline of respective teacher for details.)

title: Researching Action in Mathematics Teaching
requirements: For students in MSc Mathematics Education
description: This course is designed to raise the awareness of participants who wish to improve their teaching in mathematics lessons through recurrent hermeneutic cycles of researching process. Mathematics education research is to be explored with the focus being drawn on the discussion of teacher-as-researcher movement. Through critical reflection, the participants are to explore the sense-making process of mathematics learning via researching action in mathematics lessons.
outcome: Upon completion of this class, the learner will be able to:  1. Define the characteristics of action research and professional noticing.  2. Compare and contrast action research with other types of research.  3. Relate action research to current teaching practices. 4. Understand different types of data collection and analysis in a classroom setting.  5. Analyze different types of data collected during an action research project.  (Individual course teachers may update the learning outcome as and whenever necessary.)
syllabus: 1. What is action research? 2. Action research designs and common mathematics education research methodologies 3. Preparing and critiquing action research 4. The discipline of noticing  (For reference only, please refer to the course outline of respective teacher for details.)

title: Project and Research Report: Mathematics Education
requirements: For students in MSc Mathematics Education
description: The participants are expected to conduct guided independent studies, and on completion, to submit a research report within the area of mathematics education. The exact titles of the projects of investigation and the supervision schedules are to be negotiated between supervisors and participant.
outcome: After taking this course, students will be able to:1. Demonstrate the application of knowledge and method to the investigation of a specific area within the field of Mathematics Education.2. Identify an issue to which solutions and/or recommendations can be addressed; and produce a written report which sets out clearly the aims, context, content and outcome.3. Integrate the skills and knowledge which have been taught in the degree programme with specific application to a topic to produce a well-argued report.(Individual course teachers may update the learning outcome as and whenever necessary.)
